Row.Text: [COLOR_POSITIVE_TEXT]Health[ENDCOLOR] is one of the new gameplay elements added by Cities in Development. It is the measurement of a city's habitability and is used to offset Disease. When a city has more Health than Disease, that Health contributes directly toward Food.[NEWLINE][NEWLINE][COLOR_POSITIVE_TEXT]Disease[ENDCOLOR] is the opposite to Health. When a city has more Disease than Health, it may enter a period of Plague after too long. Disease is increased by Population, certain Features, Trade Routes, and certain Buildings.

A city's [COLOR_POSITIVE_TEXT]Health[ENDCOLOR] is increased through the construction of buildings such as the Apothecary. It is also increased by a variety of Beliefs, Policies, Wonders, and other Buildings. There are also a numer of ways to reduce Disease.

[COLOR_POSITIVE_TEXT]Plague[ENDCOLOR] is a temporary state in which the city is defensively weak and in which Citizens consume additional Food. A period of Plague will occur if a city is more Diseased than it is Healthy for too long.
+2 [ICON_PEACE] Faith and +3 [ICON_JFD_HEALTH] Health from Natural Wonders
+1 [ICON_JFD_HEALTH] Health from Marsh and Flood Plains
Doctor specialists yield +1 [ICON_JFD_HEALTH] Health and +1 [ICON_PEACE] Faith
The Apothecary boosts the city's [ICON_JFD_HEALTH] Health. The city must possess a Herbalist before it can construct an Apothecary.

An apothecary is the name of a person who researches and creates herbal medicines (it's also the name of his business establishment). In ancient Persia, the practice of medicine was split between two professions. The "ashpiu" was a sort of sorcerer or witch-doctor, who determined the spiritual cause of the ailment and prescribed the religious and magical rituals necessary for a cure. The ashpiu could also refer the patient to an apothecary or "asu," a combination of pharmacist and physician, who would provide the necessary medicines and treatments to cure the ailment.

The Aqueduct decreases the amount of [ICON_FOOD] Food a city needs to increase in size. It also increases the [ICON_JFD_HEALTH] Health output of Lake and River Tiles. Build Aqueducts in cities that you want to grow large over time.
+1 [ICON_JFD_HEALTH] Health on Lake and River Tiles.[NEWLINE][NEWLINE]
[NEWLINE][NEWLINE]City must be built next to a River.

+1 [ICON_JFD_HEALTH] Health on Lake Tiles.[NEWLINE][NEWLINE]40% of [ICON_FOOD] Food is carried over after a new [ICON_CITIZEN] Citizen is born.[NEWLINE][NEWLINE]City must NOT be built next to a River.

The Cistern decreases the amount of [ICON_FOOD] Food a city needs to increase in size. It also increases the [ICON_JFD_HEALTH] Health output of Lake Tiles. Build Cisterns in cities that you want to grow large over time, if they aren't on a river.

A cistern is a waterproof receptacle for holding liquids, usually water. Cisterns are often built to catch and store rainwater. Cisterns are distinguished from wells by their waterproof linings. Modern cisterns range in capacity from a few litres to thousands of cubic metres, effectively forming covered reservoirs.
The Grain Elevator is a Modern-era building. It's useful when you want to create a large city, fast.

In the grain trade, a grain elevator is a tower containing a bucket elevator or a pneumatic conveyor, which scoops up grain from a lower level and deposits it in a silo or other storage facility. In most cases, the term "grain elevator" also covers the entire elevator complex (an example of pars pro toto), including receiving and testing offices, weighbridges, storage facilities etc. It may also mean organizations that operate or control several individual elevators, in different locations. In Australia the term grain elevator refers to the lifting mechanism only.
+1 [ICON_JFD_HEALTH] Health on [ICON_RES_COCOA] Cocoa, [ICON_RES_SPICES] Spices, and [ICON_RES_SUGAR] Sugar.[NEWLINE][NEWLINE]City must have at least one of these resources improved nearby.

The Grocer is a early-game building designed to boost the [ICON_JFD_HEALTH] Health output of various Luxury Resources. A city must have a source of one of these resources before it can build a Grocer.

Beginning as early as the 14th century, a grocer (or "purveyor") was a dealer in comestible dry goods such as spices, peppers, sugar, and (later) cocoa, tea and coffee. These items were bought in bulk, hence the term grocer from the French "grossier" meaning wholesaler, this term derived from Medieval Latin "grossarius" from which we also derive the word gross (meaning a quantity of twelve dozen, or 144). As increasing numbers of staple foodstuffs became available in cans and other less-perishable packaging, the trade expanded its province. Today, grocers deal in a wide range of staple food-stuffs including such perishables as meats, produce and dairy products. Such goods are, hence, groceries.
+1 [ICON_JFD_HEALTH] Health on [ICON_RES_CRAB] Crab, [ICON_RES_FISH] Fish, [ICON_RES_PEARLS] Pearls, and [ICON_RES_WHALE] Whale.[NEWLINE][NEWLINE]
+1 [ICON_JFD_HEALTH] Health on Flood Plain and Jungle Tiles.
The Herbalist boosts the city's [ICON_JFD_HEALTH] Health. It also increases [ICON_JFD_HEALTH] Health from any Flood Plains or Jungles near to the City.

Herbalism is use of plants for medicinal purposes, and the study of such use. Plants have been the basis for medical treatments through much of human history, and such traditional medicine is still widely practiced today. Modern medicine recognizes herbalism as a form of alternative medicine, as the practice of herbalism is not strictly based on evidence gathered using the scientific method. Modern medicine, does, however, make use of many plant-derived compounds as the basis for evidence-tested pharmaceutical drugs, and phytotherapy works to apply modern standards of effectiveness testing to herbs and medicines that are derived from natural sources.
-33% [ICON_JFD_DISEASE] Disease from [ICON_CITIZEN] Population.[NEWLINE][NEWLINE]City must have a Apothecary.

The Hospital is an Industrial-era building. It boosts the city's [ICON_JFD_HEALTH] Health and reduces [ICON_JFD_DISEASE] Disease from [ICON_POPULATION] Population. The city must possess an Apothecary before it can construct a Hospital.
+1 [ICON_PRODUCTION] Production and +1 [ICON_JFD_HEALTH] Health from each worked Forest tile.

The Longhouse is the Iroquois unique building, replacing the Workshop. It increases the city's [ICON_PRODUCTION] Production and [ICON_JFD_HEALTH] Health output for each forest within the city's radius.
Each source of [ICON_RES_INCENSE] Incense and [ICON_RES_WINE] Wine worked by this City produce +1 [ICON_PEACE] Faith, +1 [ICON_CULTURE] Culture, and +1 [ICON_JFD_HEALTH] Health.
Monasteries increase a city's [ICON_PEACE] Faith, [ICON_CULTURE] Culture, and [ICON_JFD_HEALTH] Health output, especially if the city is near to improved Incense and/or Wine resources.
Provides 2 [ICON_RES_ALUMINUM] Aluminum. Maximum of 5 of these buildings in your empire. Eliminates [ICON_JFD_DISEASE] Disease from Buildings.
Each Recycling Center provides 2 [ICON_RES_ALUMINUM] Aluminum. Maximum of 5 of these buildings in your empire. Also eliminates all [ICON_JFD_DISEASE] Disease produced by Buildings in the city.

+1 [ICON_JFD_HEALTH] Health on [ICON_RES_BANANA] Banana, [ICON_RES_BISON] Bison, [ICON_RES_COW] Cattle, [ICON_RES_DEER] Deer, [ICON_RES_FISH] Fish, and [ICON_RES_SHEEP] Sheep.[NEWLINE][NEWLINE]City must have at least one of these resources improved nearby.

The Supermarket is a late-game building designed to boost the [ICON_JFD_HEALTH] Health output of various Bonus Resources. A city must have a source of one of these resources before it can build a Supermarket.

Supermarkets are large, self-service retail stores that sell a wide variety of food items and household goods to the general public. The first true supermarket, King Kullen, was established in 1930 in the borough of Queens, New York City, by Michael Cullen. Improved storage techniques and refrigeration allowed supermarkets to stock and sell perishable foods in large quantities, reducing the price to the consumer. The combination of ready availability and low prices made the supermarket an instant success in the U.S. during the years of the Great Depression. The supermarket continues to grow in popularity in countries around the world.
Unit will be consumed.[NEWLINE][NEWLINE]Great Tile Improvements will connect Strategic Resources on this tile to the trade network.

A sanatorium (also spelled sanitorium and sanitarium) is a medical facility for long-term illness, most typically associated with treatment of tuberculosis (TB) before antibiotics. A distinction is sometimes made between "sanitarium" (a kind of health resort, as in the Battle Creek Sanitarium) and "sanatorium" (a hospital).
This order will consume the unit and removes the city's [ICON_JFD_PLAGUE] Plague and any progress toward [ICON_JFD_PLAGUE] Plague.
Unit must be stationed in a city.
This order will consume the unit and grant +1 [ICON_CITIZEN] Citizen in all cities.
Unit must be stationed in a city.

[COLOR_POSITIVE_TEXT]Piety[ENDCOLOR] increases the [ICON_PEACE] Faith of empires.[NEWLINE][NEWLINE]Adopting Piety allows you to build Shrines and Temples in half the usual time. Unlocks building the Great Mosque of Djenne.[NEWLINE][NEWLINE]Adopting all Policies in the Piety tree causes a Great Prophet to appear and Holy Sites provide +3 [ICON_CULTURE] Culture. It also allows the purchase of Great Doctors with [ICON_PEACE] Faith starting in the Industrial Era.
[COLOR_POSITIVE_TEXT]Organized Religion[ENDCOLOR][NEWLINE]+1 [ICON_PEACE] Faith and +1 [ICON_JFD_HEALTH] Health from Shrines and Temples.

[COLOR_POSITIVE_TEXT]Tradition[ENDCOLOR] is best for small empires.[NEWLINE][NEWLINE]Adopting Tradition greatly increases the rate of border expansion in cities and also grants 3 [ICON_CULTURE] Culture in the [ICON_CAPITAL] Capital. Unlocks building the Hanging Gardens.[NEWLINE][NEWLINE]Adopting all Policies in the Tradition tree will grant +15% [ICON_FOOD] Growth and a free Aqueduct or Cistern in your first 4 cities (up to 2 of each). It also allows the purchase of Great Engineers with peace Faith starting in the Industrial Era.

Decreases [ICON_JFD_PLAGUE] Plague chance by 25%.[NEWLINE][NEWLINE]All newly trained Units in this City begin with the Medic promotion.[NEWLINE][NEWLINE]Must have built a Hospital in all Cities. The cost goes up the more cities there are in the empire.
The Red Cross decreases the chance of [ICON_JFD_PLAGUE] Plague breaking out in your empire. A civilization must have a Hospital in all cities before it can construct the Red Cross.

While fundamentally in conflict with the destructive goals of war, physicians must still proffer aid to those in need. The practice of repairing the personal damage of war, sometimes actually during the fight itself, has a number of benefits beyond the obvious. A paramount one is that of morale, since the soldiers of an army that contains surgeons are assured care if they fall in battle.

[COLOR_POSITIVE_TEXT]Heal this Unit[ENDCOLOR] 50 HP. Doing so will [COLOR_POSITIVE_TEXT]Consume this Opportunity[ENDCOLOR] to choose a Promotion.[NEWLINE][NEWLINE][COLOR_NEGATIVE_TEXT]Plagued[ENDCOLOR] status will be removed.

Takes 2 damage per turn and cannot heal. May spread this promotion through Combat.[NEWLINE][NEWLINE][COLOR_POSITIVE_TEXT]Lost with Upgrade and when garrisoned in a city with excess [ICON_JFD_HEALTH] Health for at least 1 Turn.[ENDCOLOR]
Create Doctors to increase the empire's [ICON_JFD_HEALTH] Health and to speed the creation of Great Doctors.
[NEWLINE][TAB][TAB]"As to diseases, make a habit of two things - to help or at least to do no harm."[NEWLINE] - Hippocrates [NEWLINE][TAB]

Primitive man attributed the onset of serious disease as the influence of the gods, or possession by evil spirits. Over time, however, it was found that such "possessions" could be treated through the use of elixirs made from plant extracts. Methods were also developed to clean and treat wounds, and set fractured bones. The ancient Greeks established the first schools to teach medical sciences circa 500 BC. The texts produced by the students of these schools, most notably Hippocrates, who is considered the father of medicine, based his theories of the human body on observation and reasoning rather than supernatural intervention.[NEWLINE][NEWLINE]Continued study of diseases over the years, combined with the dissection and study of the human body in the 13th century, pointed out flaws in early Greek theories, and led to more accurate medical texts based on detailed analysis rather than conjecture. By the 18th century, the same methods of analysis and observation used by scientists in other fields were applied to the study of medicine. This paved the way for the increasingly effective methods of treatment and surgery that have prevailed over the last 200 years.
Allows you to construct the [COLOR_POSITIVE_TEXT]Apothecary[ENDCOLOR], which increases a city's [ICON_JFD_HEALTH] Health.

Replace.Text: Allows you to build a handful of specialized Wonders which improve your [ICON_PEACE] Faith output.

Row.Text: [COLOR_POSITIVE_TEXT]Decriminalization[ENDCOLOR][NEWLINE]Reduces [ICON_JFD_CRIME_BLACK] Crime from [ICON_JFD_CRIME_PINK] Drug Abuse, [ICON_JFD_CRIME_RED] Treason, [ICON_JFD_CRIME_PURPLE] Vandalism by 20% in all Cities.

"Great Doctors" are at the forefront of medicine, helping to extend and support human life. They seek out new cures for diseases, guide people to lead fulfilling lives, and help us to understand the human condition.

A Great Doctor can construct the special Sanatorium improvement, which, when worked, provides a lot of [ICON_JFD_HEALTH] Health for a city. The Great Doctor may also be expended to increase the [ICON_CITIZEN] Population of all cities by +1. A Great Doctor may also be used to cure [ICON_JFD_PLAGUE] Plague from all Cities and to reset their Plague counter to 0. A Great Doctor begins with the [COLOR_POSITIVE_TEXT]Medic[ENDCOLOR] promotion.
Enemy land Units must expend 1 extra [ICON_MOVES] movement per Tile inside your territory. Provides Walls for free in all Cities. Upon discovering Dynamite, The Great Wall becomes obsolete.
Provides a free Garden in the city in which it is built. +1 [ICON_JFD_HEALTH] Health from every Garden.
+25% [ICON_JFD_HEALTH] Excess Health is stored as [ICON_FOOD] Food each turn. Provides a free Aqueduct in the city in which it is built.[NEWLINE][NEWLINE]City must be built next to a River.
[NEWLINE]"Will anybody compare the Pyramids, or those useless though renowned works of the Greeks, with these aqueducts?"[NEWLINE] - Frontinus[NEWLINE]

The Pont du Gard is an ancient Roman aqueduct that crosses the Gardon River in the south of France. Located near the town of Vers-Pont-du-Gard, the bridge is part of the Nîmes aqueduct, a 50-kilometer system built in the first century AD to carry water from a spring at Uzès to the Roman colony of Nemausus (Nîmes). Because of the uneven terrain between the two points, the mostly underground aqueduct followed a long, winding route that called for a bridge across the gorge of the Gardon River. The Pont du Gard is the highest of all elevated Roman aqueducts, and, along with the Aqueduct of Segovia, one of the best preserved. It was added to UNESCO's list of World Heritage Sites in 1985 because of its historical importance.
